awd_titl_txt: Solution-Grown Ternary Dichalcogenides: Toward Earth-Abundant Semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Semiconductors are key to many technological applications including energy conversion, telecommunications, and light emitting devices. Unfortunately, many semiconductors contain toxic elements, such as lead or arsenic, while others contain relatively scarce elements or elements that are found only in specific regions on the Earth. With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Javier Vela at Iowa State University investigates Earth-abundant semiconductors that could have useful properties for the generation of electricity from varied sources, ranging from sunlight to waste heat recycling.  In addition to improving sustainability, this project aims to broaden participation by recruiting and training the next generation of highly qualified and diverse scientists. Internships for students from a Historically Black College and University (HBCU) and a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), and participation in the Iowa State University's Science Bound and Preparing Future Faculty programs help advance basic research and education while addressing major societal challenges.

The scientific objectives of this grant are to develop the colloidal synthesis of NaBiE2 (E=S, Se) semiconductors, unveil the surface chemistry of NaBiE2 nanoparticles, and investigate structure-property relationships of NaBiE2 semiconductors and their devices. Synergy between spectroscopy and computations enables direct observation of the lowest energy superstructures that result from the mixed cation sites in the rock salt lattice. By unlocking a new class of low cost and environmentally friendly ternary semiconductors, this research leads to vertical improvements in the fundamental understanding and practical application of these compounds. This understanding helps advance the chemical knowledge of nanoscopic structures, their surface chemistry, and functionalization. In this way, this research promotes sustainability through transformative approaches to nanomaterials synthesis using Earth-abundant elements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As part of this grant from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Javier Vela at Iowa State University investigated a family of ternary—made up of three different elements—semiconductor nanocrystals that could have useful properties for the generation of electricity from varied sources, ranging from sunlight to waste heat recycling. Specifically, Prof. Vela and his group developed the composition- and particle size-controlled synthesis—from two to sixty nanometers— of I-V-VI2 nanocrystals (where I and V are alkali and pnictogen elements such as sodium and antimony, respectively, and VI is a chalcogen such as sulfur). They used X-ray scattering, computations, and spectroscopy to characterize the internal structure of these materials. Further, they unveiled how their surface chemistry impacts their ability to form conductive films that can be used in devices for energy conversion. These efforts emphasized the use of metal hydrides as versatile, commercially available precursors for the synthesis of alkali-containing nanocrystals, and was successfully extended to layered semiconductors.

Intellectual Merit: The results of this research will help unlock a new class of low cost and environmentally friendly nanoscale semiconductors, leading to vertical, rather than incremental improvements in our understanding of their chemistry as well as in our ability to use them in new clean and sustainable energy technologies. This will positively impact basic research that addresses fundamental questions and advances chemical knowledge of nanoscopic structures, their physicochemical properties, and chemical reactivity. In this way, Vela directly addressed NSF program priorities in systems that may exhibit quantum confinement, as well as improving the sustainability of resources for future generations. This work resulted in eleven peer-reviewed scientific journal articles, as well as several talks and poster presentations by the PI and the students involved in the project. These included invited seminars at national and international universities, institutes, and venues such as American Chemical Society national meetings and Gordon Research Conferences, Nano@IowaState, and the Midwest Retreat for Diversity in Chemistry.

Broader Impacts: Work under this award aimed at broadening participation by training the next generation of diverse scientists. Ten graduate and five undergraduate students and one postdoc participated in this research. Of these, nine were women, and five were under-represented minorities. Two former members are in tenure-track academic positions. Two former undergraduates are pursuing chemistry graduate school, one as an NSF Graduate Research Fellow. All participants benefitted from a wide range of educational and career development opportunities. Some went to user facilities such as the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory. Several graduate students learned to perform density functional theory and other electronic structure calculations. In this way, students widened their skillset, which significantly enhanced the impact of this NSF funded research. Multiple participants enthusiastically joined in education and outreach activities. To help mitigate some of the early impact of the COVID pandemic, Vela teamed up with chemists from the US, Europe, and Latin America to introduce the first LatinXChem virtual chemistry conference in 2020. Bringing together the research of over twelve hundred chemistry students, postdocs, and practitioners from forty-one countries, this two-week conference included a week of online poster sessions followed by another week of webinars. This conference has continued under renewed leadership in 2021, 2022, and 2023.
